Description: Dome-shaped weight carved from greyish black hard stone, likely basalt; carinated dome type with soft edge; of truncated conical shape, with flat base and very slightly convex top; smoothed surface; quite polished surface; complete.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Oriental Institute, University of Chicago. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Dome-shaped weights, including sub-domed types, represent one of the most common weights found in Naukratis, and elsewhere in Egypt (Petrie 1886, Pl. XXIII, “sub-domed” type; Cour-Marty 1990, 25, fig. 3, fig. 13). They are often made out of igneous rock such as basalt and diorite – which is the case for this specimen. Already present in the Old Kingdom, this type is particularly common on Late Period sites in the Delta (Cour-Marty 1990, 25, fig. 26). Dome-shaped weights are more often associated to the Egyptian standard deben-kedet (usually around 90-95 g and 9-9,5 g for this type) and their multiples or sub-multiples. However a lighter unit, around 8g, is also noticed and could correspond to other standards such as the Near Eastern shekel or the Greek stater (Cour-Marty 1990, 24-25, fig. 22-24; Kroll 2003, 317; Gerritt van Alfen, P. 2002, 184, n. 654). This is probably the case of this specimen which could correspond more specifically to 1 shekel. Cour-Marty, M.-A. 1989. Les poids dans l’Égypte ancienne, Vols. 1-3 [unpublished thesis, microform], Paris. Cour-Marty, M.-A. 1990, 'Les poids égyptiens, de précieux jalons archéologiques', Cahier de Recherches de l'Institut de Papyrologie et d'Egyptologie de Lille 12, 17-55. Gerritt van Alfen, P. 2002, Pant’agatha: Commodities in Levantine-Aegean Trade during the Persian Period, 6-4th c. B.C., PhD dissertation, The University of Texas at Austin. Kroll, J. H. 2003. ‘Weights, bullion, currency, coinage’, in N. Ch. Stampolidis and V. Karageorghis (eds), Ploes. Sea Routes …Interconnections in the Mediterranean, c. 1600-600 BC, Procedings of the International Symposium held in Rethymnon, Crete September 29th-October 2, 2002, Athens, 313-323. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I., 1884–5 (third memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London, 69-87, Pl. XXI-XXIV. Petrie, W. M. F. 1926, Ancient Weights and Measures Illustrated by the Egyptian Collection in University College, London.
